WSC-Category 1 Collaborative: A surface water management framework to counterbalance groundwater withdrawals in wetter regions of the U.S.

The over-use of groundwater is becoming a critical problem in regions historically characterized by abundant rainfall and surface water, including much of the U.S. Northern Gulf and Southern Atlantic Coastal regions. This project proposes to develop a theoretical framework and a new modeling/decision support tool aimed at better managing surface water so that it can be used to close groundwater supply gaps. The proposed management framework focuses on understanding human-water-land use interactions, with an emphasis on agriculture. The research team will explore the potentially transformative concept of integrating the social and biophysical dimensions of water systems into a unified framework for improved management of surface water resources. This includes consideration of the balance between water demand for humans and ecosystems.

The project team will develop an innovative geospatial decision support/modeling tool that can identify and evaluate opportunities to capture and use surface water to replace groundwater in these wetter regions of the US. The theoretical framework and associated geospatial decision support tool will be unique for wetter regions of the U.S. where groundwater and surface water have traditionally been managed separately and surface water management has focused largely on flood control. The tool will directly benefit farmers, land managers, regulatory agencies, and state and local government officials. The research will be integrated with education through a trans-disciplinary senior/MS-level course at UL Lafayette. Public outreach, focusing on water conservation efforts, will be part of this course. We will additionally leverage and expand existing NSF and NOAA watershed-based education/outreach projects that target graduate students and high school teachers, respectively. This project also serves as a catalyst for developing a new collaborative team of researchers interested in water sustainability.

Student Award

The graduate student supported by this project, Xiao Han, has won the 2016 American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME) Fluids Engineering Division Graduate Student Scholar of the year (best graduate student paper award) and $1,500. The awarded paper based on this NSF research is:

 

  • Han, X., Zhang, N., 2016. Impacts of Industrial Fresh Water Withdrawals on Calcasieu Lake Hydrodynamics and Salinity Concentration. 2016 ASME Fluids Engineering Division Summer Meeting, July 10-14, 2016, Washington, D.C., Paper No. FEDSM2016-7902

 

Ms. Han attended the 2016 ASME Fluids Engineering Division (FED) Summer Meeting in D.C. and presented her award paper. Han graduated earned her Master Degree in August 2017. Please refer to 2016-17 annual project report for more details.

 

The Model Enhancements

The vegetation model was developed in the 1st year of the project. The measured vegetation data were used in the vegetation model. Validation of the results was conducted in the project period. Please refer to the 2014-15 annual project report as well as the related publications [1, 3, 9] for details.

 

An enlarged modeling domain with finer resolution structures were implemented in the 2nd year of the project. In the same project period, the salinity transport model was also developed and validated with measurement data. Please refer to the 2015-16 annual project report as well as the related publications [3, 4, 9] for details.

 

The pH transport model was developed in the 3rd year of the project. Validation was conducted in the project period. Please refer to the 2016-17 annual project report as well as the related publications [7, 9] for details.

 

The small river/stream model was developed adopting an innovative approach of immersed boundary method in the 4th year of the project. Wetland flooding mostly occur through small streams and rivers connected to the large water body such as Calcasieu Lake. The innovative approach has reduced the cost of tradition modeling approach and can ensure a more realistic realization of the small rivers on the coarser mesh in a regional scale hydraulic model. Please refer to a recent presentation [10] for details.

 

Model Results and Applications

The major finding of the hydrodynamics and salinity/pH characteristics can be summarized as followings:

  • Saline water from the gulf travels through most of Calcasieu Lake. However, less saline water is in the north watershed Lake Charles
  • Gulf Intra-coastal Water Way (GIWW) has significant impact of hydrodynamics and salinity on the downstream Calcasieu Lake rather than the upstream Lake Charles
  • The pH value which is closely related to several key nutrients in water differs significantly between Calcasieu Lake and Lake Charles due to the difference in salinity. 

Please refer to the latest journal publication [9] for summarized details on this topic.

 

The vegetation model was used to analyze the following vegetation effects:

  • Vegetation effects on water elevation/flood coverage
  • Vegetation effects on sediment deposition
  • Vegetation effects on flood flow speed

Please refer to 2014-15 annual project report for details.

 

The following impacts of freshwater withdrawal from the system have been studied:

  • The impact on hydrodynamics of the upstream Lake Charles and the downstream Calcasieu Lake, shown in Figure 5
  • The impact on salinity of Lake Charles and Calcasieu Lake, shown in Figure 6

Please refer to 2015-16 annual project report for details.
